Ingest_LDD.name: Rings Dictionary
Ingest_LDD.comment: Changes are tracked in the file ChangeLog.md in the ldd-rings directory.

DD_Attribute.name: orbit_number
DD_Attribute.definition:
orbit_number if present is the value assigned by the mission for the orbit number associated with the observation.
Optional in labels of occultation observations and may be used multiple times.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (LDD version v1.8.0.0, 2020-01-28): Removed nillable

DD_Attribute.name: reflectivity
DD_Attribute.definition: reflectivity indicates I/F, a dimensionless standardized measure of reflectivity that is unity for a Lambertian surface viewed at normal incidence.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_reflectivity
DD_Attribute.definition: minimum_reflectivity indicates the smallest value of I/F within the data object.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_reflectivity
DD_Attribute.definition: maximum_reflectivity indicates the largest value of I/F within the data object.

DD_Attribute.name: axis_name
DD_Attribute.definition: The axis_name attribute contains a string that matches the axis_name attribute in an axis_array class of an associated array object.

DD_Attribute.name: sampling_interval_length
DD_Attribute.definition: The sampling_interval_length attribute provides the spacing of points, in units of length, at which data are sampled and at which a value for an instrument or data parameter is available. This sampling interval can be either the original (raw) sampling or the result of some resampling process.

DD_Attribute.name: sampling_base
DD_Attribute.definition: The sampling_base attribute indicates the numeric base of the associated logarithmic or exponential sampling interval.

DD_Attribute.name: sampling_scale
DD_Attribute.definition: The sampling_scale attribute indicates the type of scale that applies to the sample interval increments. It must have a value of either Linear, Logarithmic or Exponential.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The sampling intervals are linear with respect to the physical values they represent.
The sampling values are logarithms of the physical values they represent.
The sampling values are incremented in terms of exponential values of the physical values they represent.

DD_Attribute.name: first_ring_radius
DD_Attribute.definition: The first_ring_radius attribute provides the value of the first increment along the radius axis of an array given in units of length.

DD_Attribute.name: last_ring_radius
DD_Attribute.definition: The last_ring_radius attribute provides the value of the last increment along the radius axis of an array given in units of length.

DD_Attribute.name: sclk_start_time
DD_Attribute.definition: sclk_start_time is the value of the spacecraft clock corresponding to the start_date_time given in the label.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (pre-2020): Attribute moved to new Occultation_Ring_Profile class

DD_Attribute.name: sclk_stop_time
DD_Attribute.definition: sclk_stop_time is the value of the spacecraft clock corresponding to the stop_date_time given in the label.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (pre-2020): Attribute moved to new Occultation_Ring_Profile class

DD_Attribute.name: reference_time_utc
DD_Attribute.definition:
reference_time_utc provides a date and time in UTC format. Given in a label when time values in a table are given as elapsed seconds offset from a reference time. Unless there are compelling reasons to do otherwise, reference_time_utc should correspond to the start of a day.
Required anytime a table field is given relative to a specific date and time other than when Barycentric Dynamical Time is used (e.g., observed_event_tdb).
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (pre-2020): Made an optional attribute for all profile labels. v2.0 (LDD version v1.3.0.0, 2020-06-25): Removed specification of "Units_of_Time"

DD_Attribute.name: observed_event_time
DD_Attribute.definition:
observed_event_time indicates the instant at which photons were received at the instrument.
As a field in an occultation profile table, it is given in numeric seconds as an offset from the specified UTC reference time. The reference time is preferably the start of a day.
In a label the corresponding time interval end point values are given by the required start_date_time_utc and stop_date_time_utc attributes in the Time_Coordinates class.
At least one of either observed_event_time or observed_event_tdb, must be a table field for occultation data. Both may be used.
observed_event_time is equivalent to spacecraft_event_time for spacecraft data and to earth_received_time for Earth-based data. It is always the photon arrival time, so in this regard we treat typical spacecraft radio occultation data as Earth-based, referring to the time at the DSN receiving station. For an uplink radio occultation, this is the spacecraft event time.
Note: For occultation data, PDS prefers year-month-day format for dates rather than year plus day-of-year format. However, either format is permitted.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_observed_event_time
DD_Attribute.definition:
maximum_observed_event_time gives the largest value for observed_event_time in the associated data file. It is given in numeric seconds as an offset from the specified UTC reference time.
maximum_observed_event_time is optional in labels since the data file time interval end point values are given by the required start_date_time_utc and stop_date_time_utc attributes in the Time_Coordinates class.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_observed_event_time
DD_Attribute.definition:
minimum_observed_event_time gives the smallest value for observed_event_time in the associated data file. It is given in numeric seconds as an offset from the specified UTC reference time.
minimum_observed_event_time is optional in labels since the data file time interval end point values are given by the required start_date_time_utc and stop_date_time_utc attributes in the Time_Coordinates class.

DD_Attribute.name: observed_event_tdb
DD_Attribute.definition:
observed_event_tdb indicates the instant at which photons were received at the instrument. It is represented in the 'Barycentric Dynamical Time' system, as a number of elapsed seconds since the J2000 epoch. This is consistent with the definition of 'ephemeris time' as used in the SPICE toolkit.
In a label the corresponding values are given by the optional start_observed_event_tdb and stop_observed_event_tdb attributes.
At least one of either observed_event_time or observed_event_tdb, must be a table field for occultation data. Both may be used.
observed_event_time is equivalent to spacecraft_event_time for spacecraft data and to earth_received_time for Earth-based data. It is always the photon arrival time, so in this regard we treat typical spacecraft radio occultation data as Earth-based, referring to the time at the DSN receiving station. For an uplink radio occultation, this is the spacecraft event time.

DD_Attribute.name: observed_event_start_tdb
DD_Attribute.definition:
observed_event_start_tdb indicates the value for earliest time in the described data, and is given in elapsed seconds since the J2000 epoch.
Optional in labels; not intended for use as a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: observed_event_stop_tdb
DD_Attribute.definition:
observed_event_stop_tdb indicates the value for latest time in the described data, and is given in elapsed seconds since the J2000 epoch.
Optional in labels; not intended for use as a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: observed_event_time_utc
DD_Attribute.definition:
This attribute is intended to be used as a column in a table. observed_event_time_utc indicates the UTC time corresponding to the instant at which photons were received at the instrument.
In a label the corresponding values may be given by the optional start_observed_event_utc and stop_observed_event_utc attributes (or the corresponding values using Barycentric Dynamical Time, _tdb).
At least one of either observed_event_time_utc or observed_event_tdb, must be a table field for occultation data. Both may be used.
observed_event_time is equivalent to spacecraft_event_time for spacecraft data and to earth_received_time for Earth-based data. It is always the photon arrival time, so in this regard we treat typical spacecraft radio occultation data as Earth-based, referring to the time at the DSN receiving station. For an uplink radio occultation, this is the spacecraft event time.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.1 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v2.0 (LDD version v1.23.0.0, 2024-11-13): Changed data type from ASCII_Real to ASCII_Date_Time_YMD_UTC. Removed "Units_of_time".

DD_Attribute.name: observed_event_start_time_utc
DD_Attribute.definition:
observed_event_start_time_utc indicates the UTC value for earliest time in the described data.
It is part of a start/stop pair. If one of observed_event_start_time_utc and observed_event_stop_time_utc is used, both must be used.

DD_Attribute.name: observed_event_stop_time_utc
DD_Attribute.definition:
observed_event_stop_time_utc indicates the UTC value for latest time in the described data.
It is part of a start/stop pair. If one of observed_event_start_time_utc and observed_event_stop_time_utc is used, both must be used.

DD_Attribute.name: spacecraft_event_time
DD_Attribute.definition:
spacecraft_event_time indicates the instant at which an event occurred at the spacecraft, e.g., the arrival or departure of a photon. Required table field for radio occultation data, but not used in stellar occultation data. The time is given in numeric seconds as an offset from the specified UTC reference time. The reference time is preferably the start of a day, and is required to be given in the label using the attribute reference_time_utc.
Additionally, in radio occultation labels the corresponding time interval end point values are given by the required start_spacecraft_event_time_utc and stop_spacecraft_event_time_utc attributes.

DD_Attribute.name: spacecraft_event_start_time_utc
DD_Attribute.definition:
spacecraft_event_start_time_utc gives the UTC time corresponding to the earliest time given by spacecraft_event_time in the data table. However, while spacecraft_event_time is given as seconds offset from a reference time, spacecraft_event_start_time_utc is given as a UTC date time.
Required in the label for radio occultation data. Not used for stellar occultations.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v2.0 (LDD version v1.23.0.0, 2024-11-13): Changed data type from ASCII_Real to ASCII_Date_Time_YMD_UTC.

DD_Attribute.name: spacecraft_event_stop_time_utc
DD_Attribute.definition:
spacecraft_event_stop_time_utc gives the UTC time corresponding to the latest time given by spacecraft_event_time in the data table. However, while spacecraft_event_time is given as seconds offset from a reference time, spacecraft_event_stop_time_utc is given as a UTC date time.
Required in the label for radio occultation data. Not used for stellar occultations.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v2.0 (LDD version v1.23.0.0, 2024-11-13): Changed data type from ASCII_Real to ASCII_Date_Time_YMD_UTC.

DD_Attribute.name: earth_received_time
DD_Attribute.definition:
earth_received_time provides the time at which telemetry or other photons were received on Earth. Intended to be used as a table field which is optional for stellar occultations, and is not used for radio occultation data (one of either observed_event_time or observed_event_tdb is used instead). earth_received_time is given in numeric seconds as an offset from the specified UTC reference time. The reference time is preferably the start of a day, and is required to be given in the label using the attribute reference_time_utc.
This is equivalent to OBSERVED_EVENT_TIME for radio occultations. It is an optional table field for stellar occultations and is not used for radio occultations. When earth_received_time is used, the attribute reference_time_utc is required in the label.

DD_Attribute.name: earth_received_start_time_utc
DD_Attribute.definition:
earth_received_start_time_utc gives the UTC time corresponding to the earliest time for the data product at which telemetry or other photons were received on Earth.
Optional for occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v2.0 (LDD version v1.23.0.0, 2024-11-13): Changed data type from ASCII_Real to ASCII_Date_Time_YMD_UTC.

DD_Attribute.name: earth_received_stop_time_utc
DD_Attribute.definition:
earth_received_stop_time_utc gives the UTC time corresponding to the latest time for the data product at which telemetry or other photons were received on Earth.
Optional for occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v2.0 (LDD version v1.23.0.0, 2024-11-13): Changed data type from ASCII_Real to ASCII_Date_Time_YMD_UTC.

DD_Attribute.name: ring_event_time
DD_Attribute.definition:
ring_event_time indicates the instant at which photons associated with a particular ring observation intercepted the ring plane. This time is earlier than the associated observed_event_time by an amount equal to the light travel time. ring_event_time is a required table field for ring occultation data. The time is given in numeric seconds as an offset from the specified UTC reference time. The reference time is preferably the start of a day, and is required to be given in the label using the attribute reference_time_utc. One of ring_event_time or ring_event_tdb is a required table field for all ring occultations.
One of ring_event_time or ring_event_tdb is a required table field for all ring occultations. Both may be used. If ring_event_time is used, the attribute reference_time_utc is required in the label.

DD_Attribute.name: ring_event_start_time_utc
DD_Attribute.definition: ring_event_start_time_utc gives the UTC time corresponding to the earliest time given by ring_event_time or ring_event_tdb in the data table. ring_event_start_time_utc is required for all ring occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v2.0 (LDD version v1.23.0.0, 2024-11-13): Changed data type from ASCII_Real to ASCII_Date_Time_YMD_UTC, fixed definition

DD_Attribute.name: ring_event_stop_time_utc
DD_Attribute.definition: ring_event_stop_time_utc gives the UTC time corresponding to the latest time given by ring_event_time or ring_event_tdb in the data table. ring_event_stop_time_utc is required for all ring occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v2.0 (LDD version v1.23.0.0, 2024-11-13): Changed data type from ASCII_Real to ASCII_Date_Time_YMD_UTC, fixed definition

DD_Attribute.name: ring_event_tdb
DD_Attribute.definition:
ring_event_tdb indicates the instant at which photons associated with a particular ring observation left the ring plane. This time is earlier than the associated observed_event_tbd by an amount equal to the light travel time. ring_event_tdb is represented in the 'Barycentric Dynamical Time' system, as a number of elapsed seconds since the J2000 epoch. This is consistent with the definition of 'ephemeris time' as used in the SPICE toolkit.
One of ring_event_time or ring_event_tdb is a required table field for all ring occultations. Both may be used.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Added to support ring occultation timing in Barycentric Dynamical Time

DD_Attribute.name: ring_event_start_tdb
DD_Attribute.definition:
ring_event_start_tdb indicates the value for earliest time in the described data, and is given in ring_event_tdb format.
Optional in labels; not intended for use as a table field.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Added to support ring occultation timing in Barycentric Dynamical Time

DD_Attribute.name: ring_event_stop_tdb
DD_Attribute.definition:
ring_event_stop_tdb indicates the value for latest time in the described data, and is given in ring_event_tdb format.
Optional in labels; not intended for use as a table field.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Added to support ring occultation timing in Barycentric Dynamical Time

DD_Attribute.name: along_track_timing_offset
DD_Attribute.definition:
along_track_timing_offset is a timing offset to the along track spacecraft position. It is the value that minimizes differences in radii of matching circular ring features observed on the ingress and egress sides of the occultation track.
Optional in labels for radio occultation.

DD_Attribute.name: data_quality_index
DD_Attribute.definition: data_quality_index provides a more precise subjective assessment by the data provider of the quality of the observed/predicted ring occultation.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (LDD version v1.10.0.0, 2020-06-25): Revised enumerated values to lower case v1.1 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Added values to support solar occultations

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Not observable - observations at the predicted occultation event time for this ring were either not recorded (for example, the star was below the horizon) or the occultation chord did not intersect the ring.
High-SNR profile with sharp edges matched by square-well model fit.
Moderate-SNR profile with well-defined midtime from square-well model fit but possible systematic deviations of observed ring profile from model fit.
Clear ring detection but less-reliable ring width and or mid-time due to noise or substantial convolution by star diameter and/or instrumental time constant.
Unreliable detection - some hint of a ring occultation, fitted by square-well model, but ~50% chance it is just noise.

No detection - Data were recorded at the expected location of a ring occultation, but no ring was observed, either because ring event was obscured by noise or (for the lambda ring) the optical depth of the ring at the observed longitude was below detectability, even if the overall SNR of the data is high.
Is not an indication of data quality. Indicates the product is a profile of the entire ring system based on the equator system of the planet.
Background is from a different occultation.
Significant fraction of Sun is outside FOV.
Some of the data are flagged for removal.
Unocculted solar signal is from a different occultation.
Observation is unusable for analysis.

DD_Attribute.name: data_quality_score
DD_Attribute.definition: data_quality_score indicates the overall quality of the data, based on a subjective evaluation by the data provider. Required in labels of ring occultation radial profiles. Normally not intended as a value for a table field.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The data is uniformly good and is suitable for quantitative measurements.

Some portions of the data have issues which may be identified in the Note Flag column of the data file or other documentation. Overall the data may be suitable for quantitative measures, but extra care should be used.
The data are sufficiently compromised that they are not suitable for quantitative measurements (although they may be satisfactory for determining the locations of sharp features such as gap edges).

DD_Attribute.name: ring_detected
DD_Attribute.definition: The ring_detected attribute is a yes-or-no flag that indicates whether a specific ring has been detected. Typically used in radial profiles of a single ring.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (LDD version v1.10.0.0, 2020-06-25): Attribute creation. v1.2 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Attribute creation.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The ring was detected.
The ring was not detected.

DD_Attribute.name: occultation_type
DD_Attribute.definition:
occultation_type distinguishes between three types of occultation experiments: Stellar, Solar, or Radio. Stellar occultations involve observing a star as a targeted ring or body passes in front, as seen from either a spacecraft or Earth-based observatory. Solar occultations are similar to stellar occultations except that the Sun is used in place of a star. Radio occultations typically involve observing the continuous-wave radio transmissions from a spacecraft as it passes behind the target as seen from a radio telescope on Earth or another spacecraft.
Required in labels of occultation observations. Normally not intended as a value for a table field.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.3 (pre-2020): Added to distinguish among Stellar, Solar, and Radio occultation types

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The target occulted the sun.
The target occulted a star.
Radio waves were transmitted through the target.

DD_Attribute.name: planetary_occultation_flag
DD_Attribute.definition:
The planetary_occultation_flag is a yes-or-no flag that indicates whether a occultation track also intersects the planet.
Required in labels of ring occultation observations. Normally not intended as a value for a table field.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Some portion of the occultation track also intersects the planet.
The occultation track does not intersect the planet.

DD_Attribute.name: occultation_direction
DD_Attribute.definition:
occultation_direction indicates the direction of an occultation track. This refers to the observed occultation track overall, not to the subset that might appear in a particular file (e.g., if an occultation includes both ingress and egress tracks, the value for occultation_direction will be both in the data products for each occultation profile. Permitted values are 'ingress', 'egress', 'both', and 'multiple'. The value 'multiple' is used where the occultation track is not monotonic over relatively short time scales. Generally only used for some Hubble-based occultations. May be appropriate for extremely long duration occultations of a high proper motion star (e.g., u36).
Required in labels of ring occultation observations. Not intended as a value for a table field.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.3 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.4 (pre-2020): Renamed from ring_occultation_direction to occultation_direction

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The projected distance to the target body center decreases with time.
The projected distance to the target body center increases with time.
The projected distance to the target body center along a portion of the occultation track decreases with time, and along a different portion increases with time.

The occultation track is not monotonic over relatively short time scales. Generally only used for some Hubble-based occultations. May be appropriate for extremely long duration occultations of a high proper motion star (e.g., u36).

DD_Attribute.name: star_name
DD_Attribute.definition:
star_name provides the identifying name of star, including the catalog name if necessary. Examples include 'sigma Sgr' and 'SAO 123456' (for star number 123456 in the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory catalog). Use 'Sun' for solar occultations.
Required in labels for stellar and solar occultations. Not used for radio occultations.

DD_Attribute.name: radial_resolution
DD_Attribute.definition: radial_resolution indicates the nominal radial size of a single pixel. Note: this value may be either smaller or larger than that of radial_sampling_interval because a derived product can be over-sampled or under-sampled. Required in labels if the value is fixed. If the value varies, the corresponding mean and minimum and maximum attributes must be used in labels and radial_resolution should be a table field.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.1 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.2 (1.13.0): Changed definition

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_radial_resolution
DD_Attribute.definition: minimum_radial_resolution indicates the smallest radial size of a single pixel. Note: this value may be either smaller or larger than that of radial_sampling_interva because a derived product can be over-sampled or under-sampled. Required in labels if the value of radial_resolution varies. Not intended to be used as a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_radial_resolution
DD_Attribute.definition: indicates the largest radial size of a single pixel. Note: this value may be either smaller or larger than that of radial_sampling_interval because a derived product can be over-sampled or under-sampled. Required in labels if the value of radial_resolution varies. Not intended to be used as a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: mean_radial_resolution
DD_Attribute.definition: indicates the mean radial size of a single pixel. Note: this value may be either smaller or larger than that of radial_sampling_interval because a derived product can be over-sampled or under-sampled. Required in labels if the value of radial_resolution varies. Not intended to be used as a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: longitudinal_resolution
DD_Attribute.definition: longitudinal_resolution indicates the nominal longitudinal size of a single pixel. Note: this value may be either smaller or larger than that of radial_sampling_interval because a derived product can be over-sampled or under-sampled. Required in labels if the value is fixed. If the value varies, the corresponding mean and minimum and maximum attributes must be used in labels and longitudinal_resolution should be a table field.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (1.13.0): Attribute creation v1.1 (1.13.0): Changed definition

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_longitudinal_resolution
DD_Attribute.definition: minimum_longitudinal_resolution indicates the smallest longitudinal size of a single pixel. Note: this value may be either smaller or larger than that of radial_sampling_interval because a derived product can be over-sampled or under-sampled. Required in labels if the value of longitudinal_resolution varies. Not intended to be used as a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_longitudinal_resolution
DD_Attribute.definition: minimum_longitudinal_resolution indicates the largest longitudinal size of a single pixel. Note: this value may be either smaller or larger than that of radial_sampling_interval because a derived product can be over-sampled or under-sampled. Required in labels if the value of longitudinal_resolution varies. Not intended to be used as a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: mean_longitudinal_resolution
DD_Attribute.definition: minimum_longitudinal_resolution indicates the mean longitudinal size of a single pixel. Note: this value may be either smaller or larger than that of radial_sampling_interval because a derived product can be over-sampled or under-sampled. Required in labels if the value of longitudinal_resolution varies. Not intended to be used as a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: ring_intercept_resolution
DD_Attribute.definition: ring_intercept_resolution is the size of edge of a pixel at the distance of the ring intercept point. If the pixel shape is not square, it is defined by the smaller of the two edges. Unlike the quantity radial resolution, these values are not projected into the ring plane.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute created. v1.1 (pre-2020): Attribute added to the Ring_Spectrum class.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_ring_intercept_resolution
DD_Attribute.definition: minimum_ring_intercept_resolution indicates the smallest value for ring_intercept_resolution in the data product.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_ring_intercept_resolution
DD_Attribute.definition: maximum_ring_intercept_resolution indicates the largest value for ring_intercept_resolution in the data product.

DD_Attribute.name: radial_sampling_interval
DD_Attribute.definition:
radial_sampling_interval indicates the radial spacing between consecutive points in a ring profile. In practice, this may be somewhat smaller than the radial_resolution because a profile may be over-sampled.
Required in labels if the value is fixed. If the value varies, the corresponding minimum and and maximum attributes must be used instead. Not intended to be used as a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_radial_sampling_interval
DD_Attribute.definition:
minimum_radial_sampling_interval indicates the smallest radial spacing between consecutive points in a ring profile. In practice, this may be somewhat smaller than the radial_resolution because a profile may be over-sampled.
If the value of radial_sampling_interval varies, the minimum and maximum attributes are required in labels. Not intended to be used as a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_radial_sampling_interval
DD_Attribute.definition:
maximum_radial_sampling_interval indicates the largest radial spacing between consecutive points in a ring profile. In practice, this may be somewhat smaller than the radial_resolution because a profile may be over-sampled.
If the value of radial_sampling_interval varies, the minimum and maximum attributes are required in labels. Not intended to be used as a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: ring_plane
DD_Attribute.definition: ring_plane indicates the plane upon which parameters such as ring_radius are based. Possible values for the Saturn ring system are 'Equator', 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E', 'F', 'G', 'Phoebe'. For the Uranus ring system values are 'Equator', 'six', 'five', 'four', 'alpha', 'beta', 'eta', 'gamma', 'delta', 'lambda','epsilon',nu, mu. An additional value, 'individual' is also defined. Note that the named rings of Saturn are in title case while those of Uranus are lower case, consistent with normal usage by the community. Required in labels of ring occultation observations.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.0 (pre-2020): Reinstated in Occultation_Ring_Profile and Occultation_Time_Series classes

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the A Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the B Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the C Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the D Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the E Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the F Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the G Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Phoebe Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the equatorial plane of the planet.
When parameters such as ring_radius are given in the data file for multiple rings, each set of parameters for a specific ring were determined based on the plane of that specific ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Six Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Five Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Four Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Alpha Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Beta Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Eta Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Gamma Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Delta Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Lambda Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Epsilon Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Nu Ring.
Parameters such as ring_radius were determined based on the plane of the Mu Ring.

DD_Attribute.name: ring_profile_direction
DD_Attribute.definition:
ring_profile_direction indicates the radial direction of a ring occultation within a particular data product. Possible values are 'Ingress', 'Egress', or 'Multiple'. The value 'Multiple' is used where the occultation track is not monotonic over relatively short time scales. Generally only used for some Hubble-based occultations. May be appropriate for extremely long duration occultations of a high proper motion star (e.g., u36).
Required in labels of ring occultation observations. Not intended as a value for a table field.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The ring radius along the occultation track decreases with time.
The ring radius along the occultation track increases with time.

The occultation track is not monotonic over relatively short time scales. Generally only used for some Hubble-based occultations. May be appropriate for extremely long duration occultations of a high proper motion star (e.g., u36).

DD_Attribute.name: time_series_direction
DD_Attribute.definition:
time_series_direction indicates the direction the occultation proceeds through the target within a particular data product. Possible values are 'Ingress', 'Egress', 'Both' or 'Multiple'. The value 'Multiple' is used where the occultation track is not monotonic over relatively short time scales. Generally only used for some Hubble-based occultations. May be appropriate for extremely long duration occultations of a high proper motion star (e.g., u36).
Not intended as a value for a table field.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Ring radius or atmospheric height along the occultation track decreases with time.
Ring radius or atmospheric height along the occultation track increases with time.
The time series includes both ingress and egress values.

The occultation track is not monotonic over relatively short time scales. Generally only used for some Hubble-based occultations. May be appropriate for extremely long duration occultations of a high proper motion star (e.g., u36).

DD_Attribute.name: normal_optical_depth
DD_Attribute.definition:
normal_optical_depth is the ratio of incident to transmitted radiant power corrected for background_signal and for the value of observed_ring_elevation (the viewing angle). Normal optical depth is defined as the observed_optical_depth times the sine of observed_ring_elevation.
Typically negative values are used to indicate the signal was too poor to allow the calculation of the value.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Added for standardized measure of ring opacity

DD_Attribute.name: lowest_detectable_normal_optical_depth
DD_Attribute.definition: lowest_detectable_normal_optical_depth gives the theoretical lowest possible normal optical depth that can be detected in the observation based on the background signal and unocculted signal measurements.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Added to Occultation_Time_Series

DD_Attribute.name: highest_detectable_normal_optical_depth
DD_Attribute.definition: highest_detectable_normal_optical_depth gives the theoretical highest possible normal optical depth that can be detected in the observation based on the background signal and unocculted signal measurements.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Added to Occultation_Time_Series

DD_Attribute.name: highest_detectable_opacity
DD_Attribute.definition:
highest_detectable_opacity indicates the sensitivity of a ring occultation data set to nearly opaque rings. It specifies the rough value for the largest normal ring opacity that can be detected in the data at the resolution provided, incorporating both statistical effects and calibration uncertainties.
-1.0 indicates the signal was too poor to allow the calculation of the value.
Strongly recommended in labels of ring occultation observations. Not intended as a value for a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: lowest_detectable_opacity
DD_Attribute.definition:
lowest_detectable_opacity indicates the sensitivity of a ring occultation data set to nearly opaque rings. It specifies the rough value for the smallest normal ring opacity that can be detected in the data at the resolution provided, incorporating both statistical effects and calibration uncertainties.
-1.0 indicates the signal was too poor to allow the calculation of the value.
Strongly recommended in labels of ring occultation observations. Not intended as a value for a table field.

DD_Attribute.name: background_signal
DD_Attribute.definition:
background_signal indicates the anticipated signal (in counts, counts per second, or other specified units) received when no occulted source signal reaches the detector. This is the signal level that indicates an opaque ring.
Strongly recommended in labels of ring occultation observations if the value is constant, or strongly recommended to be used as a field in the data table if the value is not constant. Normally not used for radio occultations.

DD_Attribute.name: stellar_signal_level
DD_Attribute.definition:
stellar_signal_level indicates the anticipated signal from an un-occulted star, in the absence of any background signal. This is the signal level that defines the difference between a transparent ring and an opaque ring.
Strongly recommended in labels of ring stellar occultation observations if the value is constant. For stellar occultations, if the value is not constant, strongly recommended to be used as a field in the data table. Not used for radio occultations.

DD_Attribute.name: average_unocculted_signal
DD_Attribute.definition:
average_unocculted_signal indicates the average of the signal in counts/second received from outside the rings or from nominally transparent regions of the rings after subtraction of background signal.
Strongly recommended in labels of ring solar occultation observations if the value is constant. For solar occultations, if the value is not constant, strongly recommended to be used as a field in the data table. Not used for radio occultations.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Added to Occultation_Time_Series for signal analysis

DD_Attribute.name: ring_radius
DD_Attribute.definition:
ring_radius indicates a radial location within a planetary ring system. Radii are measured from the center of mass of the planet along the nominal ring plane. Units are always positive.
Required to be the first field in ring occultation profiles. Data are always organized with ring radius increasing. In labels, the min and max attributes are required.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.1 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.2 (LDD version v1.23.0.0): Fixed definition

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_ring_radius
DD_Attribute.definition:
minimum_ring_radius indicates the smallest ring radius value in the data table. Units are always positive.
Required in label files for ring occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.3 (LDD version v1.23.0.0): Fixed definition

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_ring_radius
DD_Attribute.definition:
maximum_ring_radius indicates the largest ring radius value in the data table. Units are always positive.
Required in label files for ring occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.3 (LDD version v1.23.0.0): Fixed definition

DD_Attribute.name: inertial_ring_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition:
inertial_ring_longitude specifies the inertial longitude of a ring feature relative to the prime meridian. In planetary ring systems, the prime meridian is the ascending node of the planet's invariable plane on the Earth's mean equator of J2000. Longitudes are measured in the direction of orbital motion along the planet's invariable plane to the ring's ascending node, and thence along the ring plane. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees. Note: The invariable plane of a planet is equivalent to its equatorial plane for every ringed planet except Neptune.
Required to be the second field in ring occultation profiles. In labels, the min and max attributes are required.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (LDD version v1.12.0.0, 2023-04-18): Added as replacement for deprecated ring_longitude

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_inertial_ring_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition:
minimum_inertial_ring_longitude specifies one boundary for the ring longitude range in the data; normally the smallest value. However, for ranges that cross the prime meridian, the minimum ring longitude will have a value greater than the maximum ring longitude. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
Required in label files for ring occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (LDD version v1.12.0.0, 2023-04-18): Added to define range of inertial longitudes

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_inertial_ring_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition:
maximum_inertial_ring_longitude specifies one boundary for the ring longitude range in the data; normally the largest value. However, for ranges that cross the prime meridian, the maximum ring longitude will have a value less than the minimum ring longitude. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
Required in label files for ring occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (LDD version v1.12.0.0, 2023-04-18): Added as replacement for deprecated maximum_ring_longitude

DD_Attribute.name: ring_longitude_observed_minus_subsolar
DD_Attribute.definition: ring_longitude_observed_minus_subsolar provides the difference between the inertial ring longitude of the observation and inertial ring longitude of the sub-solar point.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Added to describe offset between observed and subsolar ring longitude v1.1 (post-2020): Fixed spelling error in definition.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_ring_longitude_observed_minus_subsolar
DD_Attribute.definition: minimum_ring_longitude_observed_minus_subsolar specifies smallest separation in ring longitude between the observation and the sub-solar point.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Added to describe minimum offset between observed and subsolar ring longitude v1.1 (post-2020): Fixed a spelling error in the definition v1.2 (post-2020): Changed definition to no longer state attribute's requirement in label files for ring occultation data.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_ring_longitude_observed_minus_subsolar
DD_Attribute.definition: maximum_ring_longitude_observed_minus_sub-solar specifies largest separation in ring longitude between the observation and the subsolar point.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Added to describe minimum offset between observed and subsolar ring longitude v1.1 (post-2020): Fixed a spelling error in the definition

DD_Attribute.name: observed_ring_elevation
DD_Attribute.definition:
observed_ring_elevation is an angle measured at a point in the ring plane, starting from the ring plane to the direction of a photon heading to the observer. This angle is positive on the side of the ring plane defined by positive angular momentum, and negative on the opposite side. Values range from -90 to +90 in units of degrees. This angle is constant for stellar occultations, but may vary significantly during radio occultations. Note: The direction of positive angular momentum points toward the IAU-defined north side of the ring plane for Jupiter, Saturn and Neptune, but IAU-defined south side of the ring plane for Uranus.
Required in the label if the value is constant for the observation. If the angle varies for the observation, the min and max attributes are required in the label, and observed_ring_elevation is strongly recommended as a field in the data table. The above definition of observed_ring_elevation is equivalent to the most common usage of the term 'ring open angle', B.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_observed_ring_elevation
DD_Attribute.definition:
minimum_observed_ring_elevation specifies the smallest value for observed_ring_elevation in the data file. Only used if the value is not constant over the observation. Values range from -90 to +90 in units of degrees.
Not intended for use in the data file.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_observed_ring_elevation
DD_Attribute.definition:
maximum_observed_ring_elevation specifies the largest value for observed_ring_elevation in the data file. Only used if the value is not constant over the observation. Values range from -90 to +90 in units of degrees.
Not intended for use in the data file.

DD_Attribute.name: mean_observed_ring_elevation
DD_Attribute.definition: mean_observed_ring_elevation specifies the mean value for observed_ring_elevation in the data file.

DD_Attribute.name: emission_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The emission_angle element provides the value of the angle between the surface normal vector at the intercept point and a vector from the intercept point to the spacecraft. The emission_angle varies from 0 degrees when the spacecraft is viewing the subspacecraft point (nadir viewing) to 90 degrees when the intercept is tangent to the surface of the target body. Thus, higher values of emission_angle indicate more oblique viewing of the target. For ring data, values in the range of 90 to 180 degrees indicate viewing on the unlit side from oblique or edge-on at 90 degrees to the unlit nadir at 180 degrees.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (post-2020): Made changes to the definition

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_emission_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The minimum_emission_angle attribute provides the smallest value during the observation for the emission angle at the target.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_emission_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The maximum_emission_angle element provides the largest value during the observation for the emission angle at the target.

DD_Attribute.name: incidence_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The incidence_angle element provides a measure of the lighting condition at the intercept point. Incidence angle is the angle between the surface normal vector at the intercept point and a vector from the intercept point to the sun. The incidence_angle varies from 0 degrees when the intercept point coincides with the subsolar point to 90 degrees when the intercept is tangent to the surface of the target body, values in the range of 90 to 180 degrees are possible for ring data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (post-2020): corrected spelling errors in definition

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_incidence_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The minimum_incidence_angle attribute provides the smallest value during the observation for the incidence angle at the target.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_incidence_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The maximum_incidence_angle element provides the largest value during the observation for the incidence angle at the target.

DD_Attribute.name: light_source_incidence_angle
DD_Attribute.definition:
light_source_incidence_angle is an angle measured from the local surface normal vector to the direction of a photon arriving from the light source. For rings, the normal vector is that on the same side of the rings as the light source, so values always range between 0 and 90 in units of degrees. For ring occultations, this value is always equal to 90 - | observed_ring_elevation | This will enable users to perform database searches based on the effective ring opening angle when they are not concerned about the distinction between northside and southside viewpoints. We have included the 'light source' prefix to the term so that this quantity is not confused with 'incidence angle', a term that is generally associated with sunlight rather than stars or radio transmitters.
Required in the label if the value is constant for the observation. If the angle varies for the observation, the min and max attributes are required in the label. Optional as a field in the data table.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (post-2020): corrected spelling errors in definition

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_light_source_incidence_angle
DD_Attribute.definition:
minimum_light_source_incidence_angle specifies the smallest value for light_source_incidence_angle in the observation. Only used if the value is not constant over the observation. Values range from 0 to +90 in units of degrees.
Not intended for use in the data file.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.3 (post-2020): corrected spelling errors in definition

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_light_source_incidence_angle
DD_Attribute.definition:
maximum_light_source_incidence_angle specifies the largest value for light_source_incidence_angle in the observation. Only used if the value is not constant over the observation. Values range from 0 to +90 in units of degrees.
Not intended for use in the data file.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.3 (post-2020): corrected spelling errors in definition

DD_Attribute.name: phase_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The phase_angle element provides a measure of the relationship between the instrument viewing position and incident illumination (such as solar light). Phase angle is measured at the target; it is the angle between a vector to the illumination source and a vector to the instrument. If not specfied, the target is assumed to be at the center of the instrument field of view. If illumination is from behind the instrument, phase_angle will be small.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_phase_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The minimum_phase_angle attribute provides the smallest value during the observation for the phase angle at the target.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_phase_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The maximum_phase_angle element provides the largest value during the observation for the phase angle at the target.

DD_Attribute.name: mean_phase_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The mean_phase_angle element provides the mean value during the observation for the phase angle at the target.

DD_Attribute.name: observed_ring_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition:
observed_ring_azimuth is an angle measured at a point in the ring plane, starting from the direction of a photon heading to the observer, and ending at the direction of a local radial vector. This angle is projected into the ring plane and measured in the prograde direction. Note that, as seen from the observer, it equals 90 degrees along the right ansa and 270 degrees along the left ansa. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
Required to be the third field in ring occultation profiles. In labels, the min and max attributes are required.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_observed_ring_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition:
minimum_observed_ring_azimuth specifies the smallest value for observed_ring_azimuth in the data file. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
Required in label files for ring occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.3 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Added to the Occultation_Time_Series class

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_observed_ring_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition:
maximum_observed_ring_azimuth specifies the largest value for observed_ring_azimuth in the data file. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
Required in label files for ring occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.3 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Added to the Occultation_Time_Series class

DD_Attribute.name: sub_stellar_ring_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition:
sub_stellar_ring_azimuth is an angle measured at a point in the ring plane, starting from the direction of a photon arriving from a star, and ending at the direction of a local radial vector. This angle is projected into the ring plane and measured in the prograde direction. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees. For stellar occultation data, this angle is equal to (observed_ring_azimuth + 180) mod 360.
It is available only for backward compatibility with previously published Cassini UVIS occultation data analysis; observed_ring_azimuth is the preferred quantity for archiving. sub_stellar_ring_azimuth is an optional data table field for Cassini UVIS occultation data; not recommended for other occultation data. In a label, the min and max variation attributes are optional for Cassini UVIS occultation data; not recommended for other occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v2.0 (LDD version v1.4.0.0, 2016-04-25): Added schematron rule for conditional requirement based on occultation type v2.0 (LDD version v1.5.0.0, 2017-04-12): Corrected definition

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_sub_stellar_ring_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition:
minimum_sub_stellar_ring_azimuth specifies the smallest value for sub_stellar_ring_azimuth in the data file. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
Optional label attribute for Cassini UVIS occultation data; not used for other occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.3 (pre-2020): Corrected definition

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_sub_stellar_ring_azimuth
DD_Attribute.definition:
maximum_sub_stellar_ring_azimuth specifies the largest value for sub_stellar_ring_azimuth in the data file. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
Optional label attribute for Cassini UVIS occultation data; not used for other occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.3 (pre-2020): Corrected definition

DD_Attribute.name: sub_stellar_clock_angle
DD_Attribute.definition:
sub_stellar_clock_angle is an angle measured at a point in the ring plane, from the direction toward a star to the local radial direction. This angle is projected into the ring plane and measured in the clockwise (retrograde) direction. Equivalently, this is the prograde angle from the local radial direction to the direction toward the star. For stellar occultation data, this angle is equal to (180 - OBSERVED_RING_AZIMUTH) mod 360.
It is available only for backward compatibility with previously published Cassini VIMS occultation data analysis; observed_ring_azimuth is the preferred quantity for archiving. sub_stellar_clock_angle is an optional data table field for Cassini VIMS occultation data; not recommended for other occultation data. In a label, the min and max variation attributes are optional for Cassini VIMS occultation data; not recommended for other occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.1 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.2 (pre-2020): Corrected definition

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_sub_stellar_clock_angle
DD_Attribute.definition:
minimum_sub_stellar_clock_angle specifies the smallest value for sub_stellar_clock_angle in the data file. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
Optional label attribute for Cassini VIMS occultation data; not used for other occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.3 (pre-2020): Corrected definition

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_sub_stellar_clock_angle
DD_Attribute.definition:
maximum_sub_stellar_clock_angle specifies the largest value for sub_stellar_clock_angle in the data file. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
Optional label attribute for Cassini VIMS occultation data; not used for other occultation data.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.3 (pre-2020): Corrected definition

DD_Attribute.name: wavelength
DD_Attribute.definition:
wavelength of the observation.
Optional in labels. If the observation is over a wavelength range, use the corresponding minimum and maximum attributes instead.

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_wavelength
DD_Attribute.definition:
minimum_wavelength is the smallest wavelength used in the observation.
Optional in labels. Used with maximum_wavelength when the observation is over a wavelength range.

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_wavelength
DD_Attribute.definition:
maximum_wavelength is the largest wavelength used in the observation.
Optional in labels. Used with minimum_wavelength when the observation is over a wavelength range.

DD_Attribute.name: dsn_station_number
DD_Attribute.definition:
dsn_station_number identifies the receiving DSN station.
Required in labels for radio occultations; not used for stellar occultations. Nillable in which case the nil_reason should be 'inapplicable'.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.2 (pre-2020): Added schematron rule for conditional requirement

DD_Attribute.name: frequency_band
DD_Attribute.definition:
The frequency_band attribute provides the one or two letter identifier for the frequency band associated with radio occultation data.
Required in labels for radio occultations; not used for stellar occultations.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Frequency range: 1.70 to 2.60 GHz
Frequency range: 2.20 to 3.30 GHz
Frequency range: 2.60 to 3.95 GHz
Frequency range: 3.30 to 4.90 GHz
Frequency range: 3.95 to 5.85 GHz
Frequency range: 4.90 to 7.05 GHz
Frequency range: 5.85 to 8.20 GHz
Frequency range: 7.05 to 10.10 GHz
Frequency range: 8.2 to 12.4 GHz
Frequency range: 12.4 to 18.0 GHz
Frequency range: 5.0 to 26.5 GHz
Frequency range: 26.5 to 40.0 GHz
Frequency range: 33 to 50 GHz
Frequency range: 40 to 60 GHz
Frequency range: 50 to 75 GHz
Frequency range: 75 to 110 GHz
Frequency range: 325 to 500 GHz

DD_Attribute.name: fresnel_scale
DD_Attribute.definition: fresnel_scale is sqrt(lambda * D/2), where lambda is the central wavelength of the observation and D is the average distance between the observer and the occulting ring. This is an average value for the entire occultation and is a measure of the limit on the radial resolution of ring structure due to diffraction. Note that the actual overall resolution is affected as well by the projected diameter of the occulted star and the instrumental time constant, if any.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.8.0.0, 2020-01-28): Added as optional attribute in Occultation_Time_Series

DD_Attribute.name: projected_star_diameter
DD_Attribute.definition: projected_star_diameter provides the projected angular diameter of the occulted star, from observer to occulting object.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.8.0.0, 2020-01-28): Added for stellar occultation calibration

DD_Attribute.name: sigma_projected_star_diameter
DD_Attribute.definition: sigma_projected_star_diameter indicates the uncertainty (1-sigma) in the projected_star_diameter.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.8.0.0, 2020-01-28): Added for uncertainty in projected star size

DD_Attribute.name: fractional_error_star_counts
DD_Attribute.definition: fractional_error_star_counts indicates the fractional error (1-sigma) in star counts used for square-well model fit.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.8.0.0, 2020-01-28): Added as optional attribute in Occultation_Time_Series

DD_Attribute.name: time_constant_type
DD_Attribute.definition:
time_constant_type distinguishes between three types of instrumental time constant assumed in a square-well model.
This attribute is required if the time_constant attribute is present.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.8.0.0, 2020-01-28): Added to support time response modeling

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: No instrumental time constant, in which case time_constant and sigma_time_constant are both zero.

A single pole filter with impulse response given by h(t) = (t/t_c^2)exp(-t/t_c) for t greater than 0, 0 for t less than 0, where t_c is the time constant. See Eq. 9 Elliot et al. (1984) Astron. J. 1587-1603.
double pole filter.

DD_Attribute.name: time_constant
DD_Attribute.definition:
time_constant indicates the instrumental time constant of the detector. See Eq. 9 Elliot et al. (1984) Astron. J. 1587-1603.
If this attribute is used then the attribute time_constant_type also must be present.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.8.0.0, 2020-01-28): Added to support time response modeling

DD_Attribute.name: sigma_time_constant
DD_Attribute.definition:
sigma_time_constant indicates the uncertainty in the time_constant. See Eq. 9 Elliot et al. (1984) Astron. J. 1587-1603.
If this attribute is used then the attribute time_constant also must be present.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.8.0.0, 2020-01-28): Attribute creation v1.1 (post-2020)

DD_Attribute.name: projected_sun_diameter
DD_Attribute.definition: projected_sun_diameter provides the diameter of the sun projected onto the ring plane radius based on the line of sight from the observer to the ring plane at the start of the integration assuming the sun subtends a circular disk with an angular size based on the distance of the central body from the sun.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.1 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Added for solar occultation calibration

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_projected_sun_diameter
DD_Attribute.definition: minimum_projected_sun_diameter provides the smallest value of projected_sun_diameter in the observation.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.1 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Added to support solar occultation geometry

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_projected_sun_diameter
DD_Attribute.definition: maximum_projected_sun_diameter provides the largest value of projected_sun_diameter in the observation.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Added to support solar occultation geometry

DD_Attribute.name: sigma_projected_sun_diameter
DD_Attribute.definition: sigma_projected_sun_diameter indicates the Standard deviation (1-sigma) of projected_sun_diameter in the observation.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (LDD version v1.11.0.0, 2021-11-10): Added for uncertainty in projected Sun size

DD_Attribute.name: pole_right_ascension_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The right ascension (RA) of the pole of the specified body, given in angular measurements.

DD_Attribute.name: pole_right_ascension_angle_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty of the right ascension (RA) of the pole of the specified body, given in angular measurements.

DD_Attribute.name: pole_declination_angle
DD_Attribute.definition: The declination (Dec) of the pole of the specified body, given in angular measurements.

DD_Attribute.name: pole_declination_angle_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty of the declination (Dec) of the pole of the specified body, given in angular measurements.

DD_Attribute.name: j2
DD_Attribute.definition: The J2 gravitational harmonic coefficient of the body identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: j4
DD_Attribute.definition: The J4 gravitational harmonic coefficient of the body identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: j6
DD_Attribute.definition: The J6 gravitational harmonic coefficient of the body identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: j8
DD_Attribute.definition: The J8 gravitational harmonic coefficient of the body identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: gmass
DD_Attribute.definition: The product of the Gravitational constant and the mass of the identified body.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.0 (LDD version v1.9.0.0, 2020-01-31): Changed unit_of_measure_type to Units_of_Gmass

DD_Attribute.name: grav_ref_radius
DD_Attribute.definition: The reference radius for the gravitational harmonic coefficients of the body identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: epoch_ring_fit_utc
DD_Attribute.definition: The epoch for the ring orbital elements given in this product. Format is YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.SSSZ and may be truncated.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v2.0 (LDD version v1.23.0.0): Changed to have value data type ASCII_Date_Time_YMD_UTC

DD_Attribute.name: semimajor_axis
DD_Attribute.definition: The semimajor axis of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: semimajor_axis_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty in the value for the semimajor axis of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: eccentricity
DD_Attribute.definition: The eccentricity of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: eccentricity_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty in the value for the eccentricity of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: periapse_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The longitude of periapse for the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: periapse_longitude_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty in the value for the longitude of periapse for the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: periapse_precession_rate
DD_Attribute.definition: The precession rate of the periapse of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: periapse_precession_rate_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty in the value for the periapse precession rate of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: periapse_precession_rate_method
DD_Attribute.definition: A flag indicating the constraints used to determine the periapse precession rate of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: fitted value.
computed from J2 and J4.
computed from J2 and J4, and five major Uranian satellites.

DD_Attribute.name: inclination
DD_Attribute.definition: The inclination of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: inclination_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty in the value for the inclination of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: node_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The longitude of the ascending node of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: node_longitude_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty in the value for the longitude of the ascending node of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: nodal_regression_rate
DD_Attribute.definition: The regression rate of the node of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: nodal_regression_rate_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty in the value for the periapse precession rate of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: nodal_regression_rate_method
DD_Attribute.definition: A flag indicating the constraints used to determine the node regression rate of the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: Fitted value.
computed from J2 and J4.
computed from J2 and J4, and five major Uranian satellites.

DD_Attribute.name: number_points
DD_Attribute.definition: Number of fitted data points for the orbit of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.

DD_Attribute.name: fit_rms_semimajor
DD_Attribute.definition: The root mean square residuals for the semimajor axis of the body or ring identified in the enclosing class.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (post-2020): Improved definition clarity

DD_Attribute.name: normal_mode_amplitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The amplitude of the normal mode for the ring identified in the enclosing class. A value of -9.99X10^99 indicates there is no normal mode for the ring.

DD_Attribute.name: normal_mode_amplitude_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty in the value for the normal mode of the ring identified in the enclosing class. A value of -9.99X10^99 indicates there is no normal mode for the ring.

DD_Attribute.name: normal_mode_phase
DD_Attribute.definition: The phase of the normal mode at epoch specified by epoch_ring_fit_utc for the ring identified in the enclosing class. A value of -9.99X10^99 indicates there is no normal mode for the ring.

DD_Attribute.name: normal_mode_phase_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty in the value for the normal_mode_phase of the ring identified in the enclosing class. A value of -9.99X10^99 indicates there is no normal mode for the ring.

DD_Attribute.name: normal_mode_pattern_speed
DD_Attribute.definition: The pattern speed of the normal mode in the ring identified in the enclosing class. A value of -9.99X10^99 indicates there is no normal mode for the ring.

DD_Attribute.name: normal_mode_pattern_speed_uncert
DD_Attribute.definition: The uncertainty in the pattern speed of the normal mode in the ring identified in the enclosing class. A value of -9.99X10^99 indicates there is no normal mode for the ring.

DD_Attribute.name: normal_mode_wavenumber
DD_Attribute.definition: The wave number of the normal mode in the ring identified in the enclosing class. A value of -999 indicates there is no normal mode for the ring.

DD_Attribute.name: reprojection_plane
DD_Attribute.definition: reprojection_plane identifies the plane onto which the reprojection is based. Possible values for the Saturn ring system are 'Equator', 'Laplace', 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E', 'F', 'G', 'Phoebe'. For the Uranus ring system values are 'Equator', 'Laplace', 'Six', 'Five', 'Four', 'Alpha', 'Beta', 'Eta', 'Gamma', 'Delta', 'Lambda','Epsilon',Nu, Mu. Required in labels of ring reprojection products.

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: The reprojection is onto the plane of the A Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the B Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the C Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the D Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the E Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the F Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the G Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Phoebe Ring.
The reprojection is onto the equatorial plane of the planet.
The reprojection is onto the Laplace plane of the planetary system.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Six Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Five Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Four Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Alpha Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Beta Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Eta Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Gamma Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Delta Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Lambda Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Epsilon Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Nu Ring.
The reprojection is onto the plane of the Mu Ring.

DD_Attribute.name: epoch_reprojection_basis_utc
DD_Attribute.definition: The basis epoch for the corotating frame. Format is YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.SSSZ and may be truncated. The corotating frame is defined so that zero corotating longitude is equal to zero inertial longitude defined at the epoch specified by epoch_reprojection_basis_utc. Thus, zero corotating longitude in the corotating frame at time t corresponds to an inertial longitude of (t-epoch)*corotation_rate.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (post-2020): Attribute creation v2.0 (LDD version v1.12.0.0, 2023-04-18): Improved definition clarity

DD_Attribute.name: corotating_flag
DD_Attribute.definition: The corotating_flag is a yes-or-no flag that indicates whether or not a corotating frame is used.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.2 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.3 (LDD version v1.12.0.0, 2023-04-18): Updated definition and spelling

DD_Permissible_Value.value_meaning: A corotating frame was used.
A corotating frame was not used.

DD_Attribute.name: corotation_rate
DD_Attribute.definition: The corotation rate associated with the data.

DD_Attribute.name: corotating_ring_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The ring longitude in the corotating frame. The zero longitude is defined as the prime meridian at the epoch specified by epoch_reprojection_basis_utc. Therefore, zero corotating longitude in the corotating frame at time t corresponds to an inertial longitude of (t-epoch)*corotation_rate.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (LDD version v1.12.0.0, 2023-04-18): Improved clarity in definition

DD_Attribute.name: minimum_corotating_ring_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The minimum value in this product for ring longitude in the corotating frame. The zero longitude is defined as the prime meridian at the epoch specified by epoch_reprojection_basis_utc. Therefore, zero corotating longitude in the corotating frame at time t corresponds to an inertial longitude of (t-epoch)*corotation_rate.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (LDD version v1.12.0.0, 2023-04-18): Added to define range of corotating longitudes

DD_Attribute.name: maximum_corotating_ring_longitude
DD_Attribute.definition: The maximum value in this product for ring longitude in the corotating frame. The zero longitude is defined as the prime meridian at the epoch specified by epoch_reprojection_basis_utc. Therefore, zero corotating longitude in the corotating frame at time t corresponds to an inertial longitude of (t-epoch)*corotation_rate.
DD_Attribute.comment: v1.0 (pre-2020): Attribute creation v1.1 (LDD version v1.12.0.0, 2023-04-18): Improved definition clarity

DD_Attribute.name: reprojection_grid_radial_sampling_interval
DD_Attribute.definition: reprojection_grid_radial_sampling_interval indicates the radial size of a single pixel in a reprojected image (a derived product). In practice, this may be either larger or smaller than the radial_resolution because a profile or reprojection may be over-sampled or under-sampled. Required in labels for reprojected images, which are expected to have a fixed grid and thus a constant value for this attribute.

DD_Attribute.name: reprojection_grid_longitudinal_sampling_interval
DD_Attribute.definition: reprojection_grid_longitudinal_sampling_interval indicates the longitudinal size of a single pixel in a reprojected image (a derived product). In practice, this may be either larger or smaller than the longitudinal_resolution because a profile or reprojection may be over-sampled or under-sampled. Required in labels for reprojected images, which are expected to have a fixed grid and thus a constant value for this attribute.

DD_Class.name: Body_Ident_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Body_Ident_Base class provides multiple attributes that can be used to identify a physical object (spacecraft, planet instrument, transmitter, system barycenter, etc.). At least one must be used.

DD_Class.name: Frame_Ident_Base
DD_Class.definition: The Frame_Ident_Base class provides multiple attributes that can be used to identify a reference frame. At least one must be used.

DD_Class.name: Central_Body_Ident
DD_Class.definition: The Central_Body_Ident class uniquely identifies the body that is the central body associated with an observation (e.g., Saturn for Saturn system observations).

DD_Class.name: Reference_Frame_Ident
DD_Class.definition: The Reference_Frame_Ident class is a base class for identifying reference frames. These are frames in the NAIF sense, i.e., three orthogonal axes with a specified orientation, but without a fixed origin.

DD_Class.name: Uniformly_Sampled_Radius
DD_Class.definition: The Uniformly_Sampled_Radius class provides attributes describing the spectral characteristics of an axis of an Array object or the rows of a Table object, in cases where the spectral sampling interval is regular and the sampling parameters are in wavelength units. The axis is identified either by using Local_Internal_Reference, or by using axis name. The latter may be simpler to use if this class applies to multiple Array objects.

DD_Class.name: Wavelength_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: This class contains the three wavelength attributes

DD_Class.name: Reprojection_Grid_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: This class contains reprojection grid resolution parameters

DD_Class.name: Occultation_Ring_Profile
DD_Class.definition: This class replaces the Radio_Occultation and Stellar_Occultation classes. It is used for all ring occultation profiles regardless of the occultation type.

DD_Class.name: Occultation_Time_Series
DD_Class.definition: This class supports occultation data organized as a time series.

DD_Class.name: Occultation_Supplement
DD_Class.definition: This class is required for all radio ring occultation calibration and geometry supplemental files.

DD_Class.name: Satellite_Identification
DD_Class.definition: This class identifies the specific satellite to which the parameters given in the enclosing class apply.

DD_Class.name: Ring_Identification
DD_Class.definition: This class identifies the specific ring to which the parameters given in the enclosing class apply.

DD_Class.name: Normal_Mode_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: This class provides the normal mode parameters if one is present in the described ring.

DD_Class.name: Global_Model_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: This class provides the general parameters used to generate a ring model.

DD_Class.name: Central_Body_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: This class provides the parameters used to generate a ring model which are specific to the central body.

DD_Class.name: Satellite_Parameters
DD_Class.definition: This class provides the parameters used to generate a ring model which are specific to a single satellite.

DD_Class.name: Ring_Orbital_Elements
DD_Class.definition: This class provides the orbital element values for a specific ring which were generated in a ring model.

DD_Class.name: Ring_Model
DD_Class.definition: This class provides the parameters used to generate a ring model.

DD_Class.name: Reprojection_Geometry
DD_Class.definition: This class provides the parameters describing reprojection geometry when the ring(s) is reprojected based on a fixed grid of coordinates (e.g., radius vs. longitude).

DD_Class.name: Ring_Reprojection
DD_Class.definition: This class provides the parameters used to describe ring reprojection geometry.

DD_Class.name: Ring_Spectrum
DD_Class.definition: This class provides the parameters used to describe ring spectra or spectrograms.

DD_Class.name: Column_Headers
DD_Class.definition: This class is meant to collect attributes that are intended for use as column headers within data products. These attributes have been defined in this dictionary in order to promote clarity and uniformity, and in turn this class is defined in order to give these attributes a logical home. Because it is not intended for this class to ever be used in a label, its maximum occurrences is set to zero.

DD_Class.name: Ring_Moon_Systems
DD_Class.definition: This is an umbrella class for all of the classes and attributes in this dictionary.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: if ((rings:occultation_type='radio') and not (rings:dsn_station_number)) then false() else true()
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: If rings:occultation_type is set to radio, you must specify the DSN receiving station number.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: if ((rings:occultation_type='radio') and not (rings:frequency_band)) then false() else true()
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: If rings:occultation_type is set to radio, you must specify the frequency band.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: if ((rings:occultation_type='stellar') and not (rings:star_name)) then false() else true()
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: If rings:occultation_type is set to stellar, you must identify the star using the star_name attribute.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: if (not (rings:Wavelength_Parameters/rings:wavelength) and not (rings:Wavelength_Parameters/rings:minimum_wavelength)) then false() else true()
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: You must identify the wavelength of the observation either as a single value using rings:wavelength, or as a range using the minimum-maximum wavelength pair.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: if ((rings:Wavelength_Parameters/rings:minimum_wavelength) and not (rings:Wavelength_Parameters/rings:maximum_wavelength)) then false() else true()
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: rings:minimum_wavelength and rings:maximum_wavelength, are a pair; if you use one, you must use both.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: You must supply the corotation rate, rings:corotation_rate, associated with the corotating frame.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: pds:local_reference_type = 'reprojection_to_array'
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: For Local_Internal_Reference in rings:Ring_Reprojection, local_reference_type must equal 'reprojection_to_array'.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: pds:local_reference_type = 'uniformly_sampled_radius_to_array_axis'
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: For Local_Internal_Reference in rings:Uniformly_Sampled_Radius, local_reference_type must equal 'uniformly_sampled_radius_to_array_axis'.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: if ((rings:sampling_base) and not (rings:sampling_scale=logarithmic)and not (rings:sampling_scale=exponential)) then false() else true()
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: rings:sampling_base is only used when the value of rings:sampling_scale is either logarithmic, or exponential.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: if (not (rings:Wavelength_Parameters/rings:wavelength) and not (rings:Wavelength_Parameters/rings:minimum_wavelength)) then false() else true()
DD_Rule_Statement.rule_message: You must identify the wavelength of the observation either as a single value using rings:wavelength, or as a range using the minimum-maximum wavelength pair.

DD_Rule_Statement.rule_test: if ($is_image_like) then //disp:Display_Settings/disp:Display_Direction else true()
